instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.BKLT_SD: What is BKLT_SD? BKLT_SD is a pin of the LED driver that goes to the voltage divider that feeds the gate of the transistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H and the backlight circuit. The LED driver will short this pin to ground when backlight circuit is ready to turn on. Prerequisites are 1) it is told to turn on via enable signal, the screen has communicated with the LED driver 2) current sensing circuit is working 3) does not detect an over-current situation such as the backlight power rail being shorted to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
threads.message: I have a macbook <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which has 20v but black screen and without gong. DHU passes without error but still nothing displayed. Trackpad vibrates, capslock does not light up. I found a low resistance on L 7670 - <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> 6ohm. Can I perform a short circuit test ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
threads.message: Strange situation. <RESISTOR>R7744</RESISTOR> was getting hot. I removed it. The short circuit was still present. Later, <CHIP>U7710</CHIP> started to heat up, so I removed it and again the short circuit did not stop.  Now the <CHIP>U8110</CHIP> is heating up. Should I remove it ? This is the first time I have this situation.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
threads.message:
You have 2.2 ohm resistors in series with <CHIP>U7710</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8110</CHIP>.
Comparing resistance to ground (ohm scale) on both sides of these resistors can tell you where is the short coming from.

Seems that overvoltage occured on the <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power rail and affected more circuits.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
threads.message: I replaced two ISL95870HRUZ but one was from the motherboard <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<CHIP>ISL95870</CHIP>). Now the MacBook boots but there is no image.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
threads.message:
Do you get USB activity?
Tested external video?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
threads.message:
usb active
there is an image on the external screen
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
threads.message:
Missing both image and backlight?
Do you get 3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL>?
<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> should go high at same time.

Did you test with known good LCD assembly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
threads.message:
Backlighting is missing.
Unfortunately I have no known good lcd.
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> 1.4V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> 3V3
<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> 
1- 0v
3- 12.5v
4- 12.6v
Diodemode D840 (red probe to ground)
pin1: 0.88
pin2: 1.2

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> 1.4V"
That's your problem; T-CON backlight circuitry requires 5V.
Check <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
threads.message:
You probably need to replace <CHIP>U8500</CHIP>.
First, check diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL>, w/ and w/o LCD connected.

"4 - 1.3v
5 - 0v"
In previous post, you've said to have 1.4V at pin 5.
And pin 4 is not used...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
threads.message:
I replaced the <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> and have 5v but still no backlight.
Now the diode test is the same with and without LCD.
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 0v
Can I connect LCD with <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
threads.message: Yes, you can test with <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>/7/8, or other T2 LCD assembly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no gong
threads.message:
I just looked at <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> schematic and may not be the same option for backlight test.
It should give image, but not sure about backlight.

Be sure all <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>-3 are good.
Post <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> levels.
Check voltage and diode mode on SCL/SDA lines.
